text: In northern Mexico they are accustomed to putting their cattle on top of a templete, so that coyotes do not eat them. From his perch, the wolf goes and comes, and looks with a rejoicing eye at the coyote that is approaching with a good-natured sniff: —Good morning, my wolf brother. —Good morning, brother coyote. —What do you do there, trembling? —You see it, taking the sun. —Why don’t you sit down and “talk” with me? —Don’t be afraid, don’t let me “get away with something”! —What can happen to you? If you do not trust me, remember that the lion, the king of the jungle, just passed a law ordering no animal to harm another. And, low, don't be afraid! —I don’t dare... —but if the new law catches you! —You don’t believe it, brother: there are scoundrels who don’t respect the law. FIN
title: El gallo y el coyote
author: Alfonso Reyes
